grattantheme 0.10.0
  • Reference
  • Articles
    • Using grattantheme
  • Changelog

    Create Powerpoint slides (deprecated)

    make_slide.Rd

    These functions have been deprecated (removed) from the grattantheme package. Use the new function `grattan_save_pptx()` instead.

    make_slide(graph = last_plot(), filename = NULL, path = ".", type = "16:9")

make_presentation(
  graphs,
  filename = NULL,
  path = ".",
  type = "16:9",
  title = "Title",
  subtitle = "Subtitle"
)

    Arguments

    graph

    The graph you want to include on your slide. Defaults to the last plot (ggplot2::last_plot())

    filename

    The filename for your Powerpoint slide.

    path

    Path to the directory you wish to save your slide in. Defaults to your working directory.

    type

    The type of Powerpoint slide to create; either "16:9" (the default, for a 16:9 orientation slide), or "4:3".

    graphs

    A list of ggplot2 objects

    title

    Optional. The title of your presentation, if you want a title slide.

    subtitle

    Optional. The subtitle of your presentation, if you want a title slide.

    Examples

    
# To take a single ggplot2 graph and turn it into a slide:
# First, create your ggplot2 object. Include your subtitle,
# title, and caption with +labs()

library(ggplot2)
library(grattantheme)

ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = mpg, y = hp)) +
   geom_point() +
   theme_grattan() +
   labs(title = "Long title goes here with a bunch of text lorem ipsum
   Grattan blah blah sensible orange",
   subtitle = "Subtitle",
   caption = "Source: blah")


# Now, create a Powerpoint slide with your graph in your working directory.
# By default, make_slide() will use the last plot you generated;
# you can specify a different object to use with the `graph` argument.

if (FALSE) make_slide(filename = "test.pptx")


# To take multiple ggplot2 graphs and turn them into slides in a single
# presentation:
# First, create multiple ggplot2 objects. Include your subtitle, title,
# and caption with +labs()

library(ggplot2)
library(grattantheme)

graph1 <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = mpg, y = hp)) +
   geom_point() +
   theme_grattan() +
   labs(title = "Title goes here with a bunch of text lorem ipsum",
   subtitle = "Subtitle",
   caption = "Source: blah")

graph2 <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(x = mpg, y = hp)) +
   geom_col() +
   theme_grattan() +
   labs(title = "This is another graph to go on the second slide",
   subtitle = "Units go here",
   caption = "Source: mtcars.")

# Now combine your two graphs together in a list:

graphs <- list(graph1, graph2)

# Now, create a Powerpoint presentation with one
# slide per graph in your list:

if (FALSE) make_presentation(graphs, filename = "test.pptx")
